Dr. David Huxley.Action: Miss Swallow mentions he prioritizes work over everything, even on his wedding day.
He considers taking the day off for his wedding but is dissuaded by fiancée who values his dedication.
Is curating fossil reptiles and working at the Museum of Natural History, showing dedication to his profession.
Plans to take the day off on his wedding day, suggesting possible issues with balancing personal and professional priorities.
Miss Swallow indicates that David values work above even his own wedding plans, showing strong professional commitment and self-discipline.
Engages thoughtfully with the brontosaurus skeleton, shares scientific excitement with Miss Swallow.
Responds attentively and positively to Miss Swallow's reminders and instructions.
Smiles and kisses Miss Swallow on the cheek in a gentle, affectionate manner.
Responds absent-mindedly and somewhat dismissively to Miss Swallow's admonitions ('Yes, dear').
Earnestly and passionately explains to Mr. Peabody the significance of the Museum and his work, showing sincere enthusiasm and desire to share his passion.
Overwhelmed by the negotiation, persistently pushes Mr. Peabody for support, potentially bordering on pushy behavior.
Engages in focused, persistent communication with Mr. Peabody to secure a major endowment for the Museum, demonstrating knowledge and passion about his field.
Responds absent-mindedly and distractedly to Miss Swallow’s instructions, showing a lack of full attention to social cues.
Tries to keep his dignity while protesting Susan's hitting his ball, but does not escalate the confrontation aggressively.
Insists on ownership of the ball politely despite Susan's reproach and airiness, showing persistence yet tolerance.
Backs away respectfully when Mr. Peabody talks to him, indicating polite deference and avoidance of conflict.
Clearly identifies the golf ball by its markings, demonstrating his attention to detail and knowledge of the equipment.
Becomes exasperated and tries unsuccessfully to assert the importance of the situation to Susan, showing some loss of composure under stress.
Attempts to take possession of the ball and maintain control over the game despite distractions.
Asks his caddy what to do next, indicating some uncertainty or hesitation in handling the situation alone.
Doggedly continues his golf game despite distractions and car crashes nearby.
Watches dumbfounded as Susan causes damage to his car, showing shock but no hostility yet.
Drops his club and runs to confront Susan, then shouts at her while standing on his car as she tows it.
Waves placatingly to Mr. Peabody while being towed by Susan, tries to maintain calm in predicament.
Looks after the departing Mr. Peabody frantically, showing concern for the situation.
Engages in a sarcastic retort to Susan ('Yes, thank Heaven -- You!'), stands defiantly on his own bumper.
Waves placatingly while being towed by Susan, tries to reassure Mr. Peabody he'll be with him soon despite his predicament.
Allows himself to be towed behind a car, losing control of his situation and delaying appointment with Mr. Peabody.
Frantically looks after departing Mr. Peabody and then aggressively jams on the brakes after sliding down in the seat, reacting emotionally rather than strategically.
Attempts to assert himself by standing on his own bumper and telling Susan to go ahead, showing a minimal effort to regain control.
Maintains calm and patience despite Susan repeatedly damaging his car and frustrating him.
Loses temper after cumulative car damage, then impulsively pursues Susan’s car causing more damage.
Comes into the bar with calm patience, responds politely to head waiter, waits for Mr. Peabody.
Accidentally sits on his hat after stepping on olive, quietly accepts the mishap without complaint.
Engages Susan with a witty, thoughtful comment after the mishap, 'I might have known you were here.'
Responds violently to Susan with 'Go away!' and stalks out of the scene after feeling embarrassed.
Tries to pretend that sitting on his hat didn't happen, showing discomfort but no kindness.
Engages in a futile six-hour search for a man, appears frustrated and bitter, and eventually leaves the scene.
Attempts to conceal the pancake on his head by making feeble passes at hiding it, then stalks out quietly.
Tries to pretend he is having a good time despite an embarrassing situation; attempts to maintain composure in social setting.
Patiently allows Susan to confront him and hold Mrs. Digby's purse without complaint.
Responds to Susan's accusations with mild humor and calmness rather than anger.
Does not assert dominance or dismiss Susan despite her confusing and erratic behavior.
Shows confusion and bluntness when not understanding the conversation about 'love impulse' rather than feigning knowledge.
Stands his ground calmly when Susan confronts him, showing an attempt to maintain composure and clarity.
Does not immediately understand Susan's reference to 'the love impulse,' indicating a possible lapse in social or emotional intelligence in the moment.
Accepts responsibility of holding Mrs. Digby's purse when Susan hands it to him, demonstrating reliability and presence of mind.
Helps by carrying the purse to return it to its owner.
Argues and struggles with Dr. Digby over possession of the purse.
Attempts to clarify that the purse belongs to another young lady.
Attempts to return a purse to its apparent owner calmly and responsibly.
Gets physically entangled in a purse struggle when being wrongly accused of theft.
Maintains composure despite the public misunderstanding and accusation.
Murderous look at Susan after confusion about the purse.
Tries to leave quickly despite Susan's attempts to explain.
Stops and stands still after coat tail is torn, exhibiting a moment of pause.
Asks Susan for help after coat is torn, accepts her help.
Questions ownership of the purse, attempting to clarify the situation calmly and logically.
Gives a 'murderous look' at Susan and walks away rather than engage further, showing frustration but not losing composure.
Starts down stairs hurriedly despite obvious potential conflict, showing decisiveness.
Does not immediately react when coat is torn, instead stops and stands still for a moment, possibly indicating control or momentary hesitation.
Puts his hands over his eyes and asks Susan to go away, expressing tiredness of people when he sees too much of them.
Realizes Susan's dress is caught on his foot, hastily retrieves it, and rushes after her to rectify the situation.
Chases after Susan anxiously to explain and resolve the misunderstanding about her torn dress.
Attempts to calm Susan by telling her to stop talking and listen.
Grabs Susan's shoulders and pulls her around to face him during a tense moment.
Puts his hand gently on Susan's arm to guide her, tries to protect her from embarrassment about her missing dress back.
Keeps close to Susan, showing concern and urgency as they move quickly together.
Addresses Mr. Peabody politely and asks to be excused while clearly anxious about the situation, maintaining composure.
Leaves Susan momentarily despite her warning about the consequences, causing tension and potential distress.
Leaps back to protect Susan from walking into an empty revolving door, moving behind her to shield her.
Spends time with Susan while she sews his coat and discusses his concerns sincerely.
Expresses frustration and worry about explaining his interaction with Mr. Peabody, showing vulnerability.
Reluctantly declines Susan's offer to accompany him due to obligation to fiancée, showing some politeness but also distance.
Leaps back quickly and maneuvers to get behind Susan, managing to get through the revolving door with her despite the awkward situation.
Paces dejectedly and holds his aching head while trying to explain the urgency of seeing Alexander Peabody, showing frustration and mental burden.
Shows awareness of time and prioritizes his commitment by noting that Miss Swallow is waiting for him at Carnegie Hall, indicating responsibility and scheduling skills.
Depends heavily on Susan's knowledge and connections to fix his problem with Alexander Peabody rather than taking initiative himself.
Expresses concern and skepticism about Susan's navigation but does so in a somewhat humorous, non-hostile way.
Shows doubt in Susan's plan yet follows her despite his misgivings, indicating trust and willingness to go along with her.
Mentions 'if you don't stop nagging, I won't help you see Boopie' in a light, somewhat playful tone.
Recognizes they have passed the same house multiple times, indicating awareness and attention to detail.
Suggests stopping to inquire about their location after realizing they are lost, showing practical problem-solving.
Voices doubt and skepticism about Susan's navigation and plan, indicating critical thinking and cautiousness.
Follows Susan to the house despite feeling uneasy and his better judgment advising otherwise, showing hesitation and lack of assertiveness.
Gently cautions Susan against acting on impulse and waking someone up at night, trying to reason calmly.
Expresses nervousness and despair as Susan insists on her plan, but does not yell or lash out at her.
Follows Susan with growing alarm, showing concern but no confrontation.
Attempts to reason logically with Susan, pointing out the risks of waking someone in the middle of the night and discouraging impulsive behavior.
Expresses resignation and despair when Susan presses the doorbell repeatedly and insists on disrupting the household.
Fails to effectively stop Susan from taking irrational actions, showing a lack of control over the situation.
Demonstrates growing alarm and paralysis as Susan attempts to climb into a second floor window, failing to intervene decisively.
Attempts to dissuade Susan from breaking the window and escalating the situation.
Stands paralyzed in horror and fails to physically stop Susan from throwing pebbles and breaking the window.
Shows horror and paralysis when Mr. Peabody is hit but quickly regains composure to chase after Susan to ensure safety.
Stands watching after Susan runs away instead of immediately following her.
Accepts Susan's reassurance about Boopie calmly after the chaotic situation.
Politely and clearly explains to Susan that he is getting married and tries to set boundaries despite the difficult situation.
Expresses genuine appreciation for Susan's help before asserting his limits.
Sincerely wishes to never see Susan again to avoid further complications.
Speaks with vehemence and firmness suggesting frustration and a desire to end the interaction.
Clearly communicates his boundaries and intentions to Susan, despite the awkwardness of the situation.
Attempts to maintain dignity and control in a chaotic social interaction.
Hesitates and struggles to find the right words, showing some discomfort and uncertainty.
Keeps calm enough to plan to call his fiancée and explain the earlier confusion, indicating problem-solving and responsibility.
Allows Susan to somewhat overpower the conversation and leaves without fully resolving the emotional conflict.
Speaks gently and carefully on the phone with Alice, showing consideration for her feelings.
Takes care to handle valuable package with tenderness and caution.
Fumbles somewhat with identification but complies politely with delivery man.
Focuses intensely on his work and the package, momentarily pausing phone conversation to attend to duties.
Decides thoughtfully not to see Mr. Peabody and instead go to Mrs. Random after reconsideration, showing deliberate decision-making.
Fumbles through his pockets to find identification for the delivery man, indicating a slight lack of preparedness.
Confidently handles the receipt and signing for the valuable delivery and moves quickly to secure the package and make a phone call about it, demonstrating efficiency and responsibility.
Pauses and returns to answer a second phone call before leaving, showing caution and attentiveness to interruptions.
Responds to Susan's phone call calmly and clarifies misunderstanding about the panther, showing patience and reasonable skepticism.
Rejects the idea of taking the panther without hostility, maintaining a neutral but polite tone.
Shows skepticism and questions the practicality of having a panther, expresses relief that the panther is stuffed rather than real.
Needs reassurance and clarification about the panther, appears momentarily confused by Susan's statements.
Frantically pleads for Susan's safety on the phone, quickly rushes to her aid despite being in the middle of other activities.
Shows genuine concern for Susan's wellbeing before asking questions or making assumptions.
Reacts with suspicion initially but quickly assesses the situation when the panther appears, showing some alertness and practical concern by trying to contain the panther and calling for help.
Stiffens and is dumbfounded when confronted with the panther, then leans tensely against the door, indicating a momentary loss of composure under unexpected circumstances.
Drags a chair to prop against the bathroom door to prevent the panther from escaping, demonstrating quick thinking and problem-solving skills in a crisis.

Insists on removing the panther and calling the Zoo despite Susan's refusal, showing a strong will to manage the situation safely, but perhaps a lack of flexibility or persuasion to collaboratively resolve the conflict.
Shows clear fear and apprehension toward the panther, tries to distance himself, expresses desire to avoid involvement with Susan's schemes.
Worried about his safety, but politely and sincerely tells Susan to ensure some personal valuables are delivered to the Museum if anything happens to him.
Backs away nervously from the panther, shows apprehension and weakness, requests a package be delivered in case something happens to him.
Attempts to reason about putting the victrola in the bathroom to lure the panther back.
Expresses clear desire to avoid involvement in a risky situation, standing firm on his reluctance.
Attempts to maintain focus on completing his brontosaurus despite chaotic distractions.
Refuses to engage with Susan's urgent requests and schemes, prioritizing his own goals rigidly.
Shows nervousness and tries to protect his fossil carefully.
Dismisses potentially important social obligations and complex problems by ignoring them.
Sternly orders Baby to go back and slams the door almost on Baby's nose, showing malice; ignores Susan's advice to promise something to Baby.
Walks away concentrating on his work, seemingly unaware of Baby's loyalty and devotion following him.
Points sternly and commands Baby to go back, raising his voice to assert control.
Jerks door open maliciously and slams it almost on Baby's nose, attempting to exclude him.
Walks away from Baby, focusing on his work and life, seemingly unaware or unable to handle Baby’s persistent following.
Concerned about the leopard following him; protests taking responsibility for the animal.
Runs to catch onto the side of the station wagon to avoid being left with the leopard.
Is too absorbed in his thoughts to notice that his presence makes people avoid him on the street.
Expresses frustration and anxiety about the trip and insists on finishing his work and getting married, showing a desire for stability.
Firmly sets boundaries by telling Susan he will not be blackmailed into further trips, showing assertiveness but not friendliness.
Tries to avoid argument and keeps composure despite stressful situation with the leopard, showing tolerance.
Firmly asserts his boundaries and communicates his limits clearly, intending to regain control of a stressful situation.
Expresses a strong and reasonable concern about the danger of having a leopard nearby, showing situational awareness.
Fails to calm the situation or influence Susan effectively, who continues to ignore his concerns and push the difficult situation forward.
Shows concern and agitation during the chaotic accident involving the chicken wagon; tries to stay calm and protect his hat despite confusion.
Allows Susan to take charge of the situation with Baby and the scattered birds, showing tolerance and trust in her actions.
Frantically waves arms and covers eyes during accident, indicating vulnerability and reliance on others in stressful moments.
Closes his eyes knowing what is going to happen, agonizedly yells a warning about the duck.
Allows Susan to handle the situation with the wagon and the animals, appears somewhat overwhelmed and frantically waves his arms while his hat falls over his eyes.
Calmly tells Susan to leave his hat alone because it will come with his head, shows some self-control.
Takes off his own hat with not too much trouble once freed, indicating some regained composure and capability.
Stares out of the scene, appearing passive and non-intervening as the chaos unfolds around him.
Warns Susan urgently about hanging on to a leopard's tail to prevent danger.
Runs toward Baby to possibly intervene after the tail slips and Susan falls.
Speaks bitterly and madly about the situation, showing frustration rather than patience.
Continues to pump the tire despite obvious complications and damage caused by Baby, showing persistence but also irritation.
Warns Susan not to hang on to the leopard's tail, trying to prevent danger.
Scrambles out of the station wagon and runs toward Baby to stop him.
Is bitter and frustrated but continues to try fixing the flat tire despite difficulties.
Fails to successfully prevent Susan from falling or Baby from causing trouble.
Argues loudly with Susan about the location of the tire puncture and expresses frustration about time constraints.
Shows dejection and exhaustion by sinking onto the running board with his head in his hands after the tire incident.
Patiently tries to fix the tire despite delays and frustration, shows persistence.
Responds to the officer's question by describing the leopard in a friendly and informative manner.
Argues confidently about the location of the tire puncture and insists on a position despite Susan's doubts.
Acknowledges that fixing the tire is taking him too long and seems frustrated but continues attempting it.
Stops pumping the tire when Susan suggests that he can't keep doing it indefinitely, shows some responsiveness.
Sinks dejectedly, head in hands after the tire repair attempt fails.
Correctly identifies the animal 'Baby' as a leopard by referring to Webster's definition in a calm, composed manner when the officer questions him.
Engages in light-hearted banter with Susan about the circus and the cat, showing tolerance for her humor.
Jokes about not looking like a knife thrower and expresses desire to be allowed to explain himself, indicating a polite and sincere demeanor.
Mildly objects to Susan's intervention with the officer but does so without hostility, reflecting friendliness though slight frustration.
Maintains composure and tries to handle the situation with the officer calmly despite Susan's interruptions.
Expresses frustration and awkwardness when Susan misrepresents facts to the officer, undermining his own credibility.
Protests but ultimately complies with stopping for necessities despite inconvenient circumstances.
Expresses frustration but does not insult or lash out at Susan.
Turns away silently when realizes argument is futile.
Objects to an inefficient plan (stopping at a circus town) and questions Susan's decision, showing awareness and reasoning.
After his objections are dismissed, he silently turns away and does not push further or suggest alternatives, showing some passivity.
Smiles foolishly and makes a light-hearted comment to ease tension with Digby at the market.
Orders an unusually large amount of meat (20 pounds) to be eaten raw without explanation, causing discomfort to others.
Orders an unusually large amount of meat (twenty pounds) and confidently specifies it will be eaten raw, demonstrating assertiveness and decisiveness.
Smiles foolishly and fails to recognize that his face is familiar to another character, indicating a lapse in social awareness or self-presentation.
Expresses frustration and weariness but continues cooperating with Susan to handle the situation with Baby and the stolen car.
Calls Susan 'Svengali' sarcastically while expressing his desperate desire to get married and leave.
Listens to Susan's suggestion about the shower and complies without argument.
Carries the precious fossil despite being weary and stressed.
Recognizes the seriousness of having stolen a car and the risks involved.
Unable to persuade Susan to avoid dishonest actions, becomes speechless and frustrated.
Expresses desperation and loss of control over the situation, using wild language and sarcasm.
Vehemently tells Susan not to touch the fossil bone, insists she put it down gently and go away.
Speaks impatiently and loudly from the shower to hurry Mrs. Gogarty off to town for clothes pressing.
Indignantly demands his clothes back to leave immediately.
Clearly identifies the intercostal clavicle of a brontosaurus and insists on careful handling of the fossil bone.
Commands Susan not to touch the bone and to handle his clothes quickly and correctly while he is in the shower, showing some control and urgency.
Becomes impatient and vocal about needing his clothes immediately, indicating some stress but also assertiveness in managing his needs.
Allows Susan to delay giving him his clothes, seemingly losing some practical control over the situation.
Expresses frantic concern about missing clothes because of his fiancee waiting for him and impending marriage.
Shows impatience and hysteria when Susan prioritizes her shower over his urgent need.
Argues passionately about the importance of his worries regarding marriage and clothing, showing sincerity.
Demonstrates anxiety and frantic behavior about missing clothes and impending obligations, repeatedly expressing worry and frustration.
Shows persistence and awareness of the urgency of his situation by continuously pressing Susan about his clothes and the need to leave immediately.
Yells at Susan with insults, calling her a spoiled, conceited little scatterbrain and predicts misery for the man who gets her.
Despite his anger, he stops before invading privacy when Susan refuses to come out of the shower.
Strides out infuriatedly pursuing an argument and yells demanding Susan to come out of the shower while clutching a delicate negligee in frustration.
Browses agitatedly, delivers an angry speech insulting Susan as a spoiled, conceited scatterbrain, showing loss of self-control and judgment.
Yanks open the door impulsively without checking who is inside, and is caught off guard by the unexpected presence of Susan's aunt and household staff, exposing a lack of situational awareness.
Feels disorganized and flustered when confronted by Aunt Elizabeth, answers meekly and honestly about Susan showering.
Does not attempt to deflect or lie about the situation despite embarrassment, maintains sincerity.
Appears completely disorganized and flustered when confronted by Aunt Elizabeth about his clothing and presence.
Struggles to answer basic questions clearly, shows meekness and inability to assert himself in a tense social situation.
Attempts to explain his situation despite obvious confusion, indicating an effort to manage the situation, though ineffectively.
Acknowledges Susan brought him here, tries to explain despite stammering.
Responds violently with 'No!' when Aunt Elizabeth mocks his clothes.
Stammers and is unable to clearly explain why he is at the location, appearing flustered and lacking composure.
Affirms and supports Susan's story despite his own obvious discomfort, showing some trust but also potential lack of control over the situation.
Insists on getting his clothes and expresses desire to be married despite opposition.
Stalks into Mark's bedroom with dignity to retrieve clothes.
Stalks into Mark's bedroom to get clothes with as much dignity as possible, showing determination and some self-control.
Speaks wildly and violently, unable to maintain calm in a stressful situation.
Puts hands on Susan's shoulders pleading sincerely for her help, showing vulnerability and trust.
Dismisses responsibility for Susan and the panther, stating 'It's your problem.'
Expresses frustration and weariness openly, showing emotional transparency.
Refers to Susan as if talking to an idiot, 'as if talking to an idiot'.
Refuses to take responsibility for Susan and the panther, focusing instead on his own urgent tasks.
Shows awareness of the political dynamics by understanding Aunt Elizabeth Random's influence over Mr. Peabody and the million-dollar donation.
Recognizes the need to keep his identity secret from Mrs. Carleton Random to secure the museum donation.
Gives a clear, focused request to Susan to maintain secrecy about his identity, showing strategic thinking.
Momentarily shows signs of weariness and frustration, groaning when realizing Susan's connection to the influential family.
Pulls Susan closer tenderly and warns her not to reveal his identity, showing concern and protectiveness.
Frantically searches for his precious fossil and involves Susan in the search, showing trust in her help despite tension.
Shakes Susan anxiously demanding to know about the missing bone, showing frustration that may border on impatience.
Shows intense distress and urgency over the lost rare fossil, rapidly searching and questioning Susan.
Allows emotional anguish and distraction to influence behavior, losing temper by shaking Susan and showing frantic desperation.
Persistently continues to search meticulously for the bone, crawling under furniture and collaborating with Susan despite setbacks.
Fails to keep prized fossil safe, loses the intercostal clavicle after years of effort and expeditions.
Slumps dejectedly showing vulnerability and frustration over the lost bone.
Coldly states the difficulty of replacing the bone, showing impatience.
Clenches his hands prayerfully, reveals internal anxiety and earnestness about his problem.
Dashes past Aunt Elizabeth without politeness, ignoring social niceties.
Expresses affection for George, calling him a 'nice dog'.
Stops in despair but continues trying to find the bone, showing persistence with the dog.
Sternly commands George and calls him 'cur' bitterly after the dog growls.
Agitatedly points out dog's dirty paws indicating concern and involvement.
Stops suddenly in despair and admits they are not making progress finding the dog’s buried item.
Observes that the dog’s paws and muzzle are covered in earth and correctly infers the dog has been digging and likely buried the item.
Attempts to command the dog sternly to reveal the buried item.
Expresses frustration and calls the dog a cur in bitter tone.
Digs enthusiastically alongside Susan and George with silent determination.
Expresses frustration towards George by calling him an 'unfeeling beast' through clenched teeth.
David digs with silent determination alongside Susan and George, showing persistence and willingness to engage actively in the search.
David follows George’s misleading lead without questioning or redirecting promptly, contributing to unproductive digging.

Participates in the physical labor despite appearing weary and irritable.
Offers to do the hard work himself so George doesn't exhaust himself.
Exits hurriedly in pursuit of George to help him.
Crawls on hands and knees after George the dog, playing and engaging with the animal despite social embarrassment.
Does not respond or react negatively to Aunt Elizabeth's harsh disapproval and exclusion, remains focused on playing with George.
Crawls through a hedge on his hands and knees after George, showing determination and persistence.
Fails to successfully catch George, falling face down and missing his grab.
Ends up exhausted and unhappy after being kept in Connecticut, suggesting a lack of control over his situation.
Expresses persistent concern about the lost bone and the progress of the dig, showing dedication to his work despite frustrations.
Admits to postponing his marriage and not informing his fiancée about the lost bone, showing anxiety and reluctance to face consequences.
Glum and hopeless demeanor, repeatedly voicing pessimism about the situation and failure to relax or adapt to changing circumstances.
Follows Susan to the stable to help feed the panther despite his bitter tone.
Encourages Susan to grab George, but ultimately protects George himself by hugging him firmly.
Makes sarcastic and bitter remarks about the panther and George.
Manages to handle George the dog despite difficult circumstances, showing physical capability and presence of mind.
Expresses frustration and bitterness regarding the panther and feeding Baby, indicating some emotional stress impacting his effectiveness.
Engages in problem-solving (feeding Baby with meat from a package he procured), demonstrating practical skills.
Delegates responsibility to Susan for grabbing George, showing some hesitation or lack of confidence.
Physically restrains George successfully, showing capability and control under pressure.
Engages patiently with Susan despite her repeated interruptions and teasing; tries to maintain composure on the phone.

Shouts a distressing message into the phone indicating frustration but also a desire to be honest and straightforward.
Politely greets a stranger (Major Applegate) despite feeling ill at ease and a bit surprised.

Helps Susan telephone, indicating some practical capability and initiative.
Does not assert himself firmly in a confusing social situation, showing some hesitation.
Remains silent and does not engage in dinner conversation, focusing attention only on George the leopard instead of others present.

Ignores Applegate's awkward attempts at conversation, showing little patience or small talk.
Focuses attentively on George despite interruptions and social discomfort.

Tries to calm Susan down by telling her not to lose her head and to collect herself amid hysteria.
Shakes Susan to get her attention and stop her shaking.
Maintains composure and tries to calm Susan down amid panic.

Despite tense and chaotic situation, tries to give instructions calmly.
Unable to immediately find or secure Baby; stall is found empty upon arrival.
David at telephone in an agitated state, reporting seeing a panther in Connecticut.
Calls the Zoo and arranges for them to take the panther away, despite Susan's distress.
Refuses to change his decision even after Susan begs him, showing firmness but lack of empathy.
Firmly prevents Susan from falsely accusing others, insists on truthfulness.
Spends time trying to convince others of his accurate observations despite disbelief.
Shows no signs of anger or frustration even when dismissed and left unsupported.
Spends fifteen minutes trying to convince others about the panther sighting but fails to persuade them.
Insists firmly against Susan's suggestion to discredit himself as a drug addict.
Attempts to make a phone call to reach others but they are unavailable.
Shows agitation and frustration about the lost George and reacts sharply to Aunt Elizabeth's indifference.
Engages seriously with Susan and Aunt Elizabeth, despite the tension, indicating a desire to communicate and solve the problem.
Encourages Applegate to try the panther cry to attract the animal, showing engagement and teamwork.
Calls Susan a 'little fiend' and says she is 'plain vicious,' 'has all the kind instincts of a cobra,' and is 'mad enough to tell the whole story' harshly.
Reassures others that Susan will be all right after she faints, showing confidence in her resilience.
Attempts to identify a mysterious scream and uses logical thinking to deduce it's an echo and possibly from a panther, showing scientific curiosity and observational skills.
Responds to Susan's odd behavior with harsh verbal criticism ('you're just plain vicious!'), showing a lack of empathy and poor interpersonal skill in a tense moment.
Remains confident and assertive when Susan faints, reassuring others about her strength and survival ability.
Calmly assesses Susan's fainting and insists on not being fooled; offers to do whatever Susan wants to help her.
No relevant actions or statements indicative of competence or incompetence in this excerpt.
Responds to Susan's singing encouragement with a bitter but honest admission about not singing and his stubbornness.
Shows concern and urgency about crossing the river safely, placing his hand on Susan's arm beseechingly.
Jumps in and pulls Susan out of the water when she starts to drown, though slaps her impatiently on the back.
Responds bitterly and savagely when Susan speaks lightheartedly after the failed river crossing attempt.
Dives in and swims to the other side, showing determination and inclusiveness by going ahead for Susan.
Yells simultaneously with Susan on seeing George and Baby, then turns on her accusingly after they get scared.
Pushes Susan when angry but then admits he didn't think about it, showing some unintentional harm but also some sincerity.
Shares a tender moment face to face with Susan and engages in gentle, somewhat ironic conversation, acknowledging his own vulnerabilities.
Admits his frustrations openly about being kept in the dark and having chances ruined, showing sincerity and vulnerability.
Chooses to stay peacefully with Susan and lets others search for them, showing trust and a gentle, friendly nature.
Mentions his darker thoughts (murder) silently to himself but continues to engage tenderly with Susan.
Expresses frustration calmly about Susan's actions ruining his chances for the Museum bequest, showing awareness of situation.
Stares off into space, stunned upon hearing Boopie is coming to the house, indicating surprise and a momentary lapse in control.
Suggests staying quietly where they are and letting others look for them, demonstrating a strategic and calm approach to the situation.
Mentions his background and relationship with Peabody in a way that reveals concern but no immediate proactive action, reflecting some insecurity.
Builds a small bonfire with Susan and uses his shirt to help dry clothes, showing care and cooperation.
Plans to find or arrange a portable bathhouse to speed up their recovery process.

Engages cooperatively with Susan to help find Baby and calmly approaches the truck men despite uncertainty.

Blocks the way and is completely unhelpful while Susan struggles with the panther.

Blocks the way and is described as being completely unhelpful in a tense situation.
Assessing that the panther couldn't have gotten far, showing logical reasoning about the animal's movement.
Following Susan promptly when she spots the panther again and responds quickly to the situation.
Not explicitly shown taking initiative in the search; often reacting after Susan's lead.

Sits down and lights a cigarette, seemingly indifferent when Susan insists he not accompany her.
Calmly responds to Susan's injured state by moving to help her after hearing her cries.
Uses condescending language (‘your natural instinct for being wrong astounds me’) after helping Susan.

Shows dull fury when Susan loses the rope, indicating frustration but no harshness.

Commands Susan to give him the rope to control Baby or the situation, showing intent to take charge.
Shows frustration and dull fury when Susan loses the rope, indicating a momentary loss of control or preparedness.
Continuing to attempt to manage the stressful situation despite complications, showing persistence.
Joins Susan and George in singing to calm the panther, attempts to participate despite limited knowledge of the song.
Responds bitterly and somewhat sarcastically when Susan suggests climbing to push the panther down.
Displays sarcasm and bitterness but does not take proactive action to resolve the immediate danger posed by the panther.
Participates in singing to calm the panther, showing willingness to cooperate and adapt to unconventional methods.
Reassures everyone by saying 'Oh, we're fine. We're just dandy' after a frightening event.
Protectively tackles George to keep him safe as Baby panthers leap near.
Firmly explains to Major Applegate that the panther is tame, showing concern for Susan and the situation.
Uses a somewhat harsh tone calling Major Applegate 'crazy' in front of others.
Suggests being open and honest to reduce confusion and increase chances of success in the panther hunt.
Tries to calmly explain the situation to Applegate and others despite tension.
Suggests that being open and honest about the situation might reduce confusion and increase the chances of success in capturing the panther.
Points out the actual panther clearly to others, demonstrating awareness of the main objective.
Attempts to calmly explain the complicated situation to skeptical parties (Applegate and Susan), showing communication skills.
Does not assertively manage Gogarty's quitting attitude or Applegate's confusion, which might undermine the group’s effectiveness.
Acknowledges the situation clearly and contributes to the planning with Susan and others about finding the lost animal.
Follows orders from Applegate and works cooperatively with Susan to search in the appropriate direction.
Does not exhibit independent leadership or decisiveness; largely follows directions given by Applegate without questioning or initiating alternative plans.
Politely refuses to kiss Susan, citing his engagement and sincerity about his commitments.
Maintains respectful boundaries despite Susan's advances, responds honestly and gently.
Carefully thinks through the difference between touching Susan's face and kissing her; communicates his engaged status clearly and sticks to his principles.
Avoids discussing why he didn't kiss Susan; is cautious and somewhat reserved in the social interaction.
Refuses Susan's kiss politely and honestly, stating his intention to return to New York and get married.
Acts cooperatively with Susan to locate the missing animals patiently and attentively, following George and searching carefully.
Identifies and pursues George to locate Baby, showing focus and initiative in following the animal under the house.
Engages in physical effort (dropping on hands and knees to follow George) to accomplish goal, demonstrating practical problem-solving.
Does not rush to sing or appease the situation emotionally; instead focuses on action and tracking, indicating level-headedness and prioritization.
Relies on Susan to sing to Baby rather than taking an alternative action himself, possibly showing reliance or omission of alternate strategies.
Does not verbally express frustration or confusion despite tense situation, maintaining composure.
Follows George patiently, playing along in a teasing manner.
Shows visible horror and distress witnessing Susan being pulled inside against her will.
Does not intervene physically when Susan is restrained and pulled inside by Dr. Digby.
David, wary, goes to other side and waits, ready to trap him.
David follows George cautiously, indicating alertness and strategic thinking.
Upon seeing Digby pull Susan inside, David reacts with horror and covers his eyes, suggesting emotional overwhelm and a momentary loss of control.
Stands dejectedly with a black eye, showing resilience without complaint.
Warns Susan not to be a fool when she tries to pick the lock.
Realistically acknowledges their dire situation in jail without panic.
Stands dejectedly in jail holding a handkerchief over a black eye, showing resignation and lack of immediate proactive escape attempt.
Responds realistically to Susan’s escape attempt by advising her not to be a fool, indicating practical judgment and tempering impulsiveness.
Shows an understanding of their dire legal situation and the improbability of quick release, reflecting situational awareness and cautious realism.
Sits quietly in a corner of his cell with his head in his hands while others protest loudly.
Sits quietly in a corner of his cell with his head in his hands while others are yelling protests.
Maintains calm and composed responses under aggressive questioning; denies wrongdoing sincerely.
Leans against the jail bars dejectedly, indicating vulnerability and openness in a stressful situation.
Leans against the bars dejectedly, appears lethargic and somewhat disengaged during interrogation.
Maintains his story consistently despite pressure, refuses to admit guilt or panic under interrogation.
Defends Susan against accusations, telling Slocum not to believe her.
Expresses wild apprehension and concern about Susan's plans not working out.
Dismisses Susan's stories as fabrications from motion pictures.
Recognizes a plan coming and rouses from lethargy to confront it, showing awareness and assertiveness.
Attempts to discredit Susan's story by pointing out it is made up from motion pictures.
Shows apprehension and panic ('wildly'), indicating a lack of calm confidence under pressure.
Fails to control the situation effectively or negotiate successfully when confronted by Slocum and others, thus not demonstrating effective problem-solving.
Struggles against Susan's clingy kiss and firmly pushes her away to maintain boundaries.
Struggles to push Susan away physically but does not take definitive action to control the situation, showing hesitation.
Remains relatively passive during interrogation and chaos, allowing events to proceed without his intervention.
Appears overwhelmed and uncertain when confronted by Susan's aggression and the police action.
Replies weakly and honestly to Miss Swallow about not having found the intercostal clavicle.
Admits to having done something wrong when confronted by others.
Confidently approaches and strokes the panther, calming the group and showing care for Baby.
Confidently approaches and strokes the panther, calmly identifying it as 'Baby' despite others' fear.
Does not panic or back down in presence of the panther, showing composure.
Raises his voice suddenly to alert others about the lost panther, showing quick concern and communication.
Shows agitation and cries out Susan's name in an agonized cry, indicating emotional overwhelm rather than calm control.
Urgently urges Susan to let go of the rope and escape danger, expressing concern for her safety.
Expresses love to Susan sincerely amid danger, showing emotional openness and care.
Points weakly toward the desk in an anguished manner, struggling to take control of the dangerous situation involving the panther and Susan.
Faces the panther and urges Susan firmly to let go of the rope and run to safety, showing some presence of mind under pressure.
Clutches vaguely for a chair behind him instead of taking decisive defensive action against the panther.
Uses a chair to protect Susan from the panther, placing himself between her and danger.
Calls out to Susan with concern and affection while confronting the panther.
Expresses emotional vulnerability and admits he is not all right after the dangerous incident.
Suddenly rejects Susan and her aunt, calling Susan a menace and declaring he never wants to see them again.
Whips a chair in front of him to protect Susan from the panther and attempts to contain the panther by closing it in a cell.
In a state of collapse, unsure of what he is doing, sinks weakly into the chair despite the panther being still active behind him.
Shouts to Susan to check if she is all right, showing concern and some control in a chaotic moment.
Exits hysterically, declaring himself defeated and wanting to avoid further conflict, indicating emotional overwhelm and loss of composure.
Despite losing an important fossil piece (intercostal clavicle), he continues to work on the Brontosaurus Group and attempts to maintain a professional demeanor.
Loses the intercostal clavicle fossil, which Miss Swallow points out as a significant failure.
Expresses emotional vulnerability but quickly regains control and refocuses on his scientific work.
Argues with Miss Swallow about his feelings, showing some defensiveness and lack of full command over the situation.
Warns Susan not to climb the ladder, fearing for her safety.
Expresses gratitude to Susan and George for the bone.
Tells Susan to put down the bone and go away, showing frustration and distancing himself.
Acknowledges the difference between science and love, indicating emotional reservation.
Warns Susan not to come up the ladder, showing awareness of danger and caution.
Refuses to immediately accept Susan's discovery and distinguishes between science and emotions, showing intellectual rigor and professional boundaries.
Appears hesitant or fearful to come down the ladder, indicating lack of confidence or decisiveness in the moment.
Expresses frustration that Susan and her panther have cost the Museum a million dollars, implying some poor management or consequences from events outside his control.
Prioritizes Susan's safety over his scientific work, frantically digs through fallen bones to rescue her, expresses deep concern and relief.
Proposes marriage to Susan in a moment of vulnerability and love after danger has passed.
Frantically tries to save Susan from the collapsing skeleton, prioritizing her safety over his four years of scientific work.
Unable to prevent the destruction of years of work due to Susan's rocking on the ladder; appears overwhelmed and helpless.
Despite the crisis, remains focused on Susan's well-being and manages to rescue her successfully.
Moment of emotional vulnerability and exhaustion leading him to propose marriage impulsively at a stressful moment.
